docs.abstract: Fed up parents, civil rights activists, newly awakened educators and lawmakers are crusading for “the science of reading.” Can they get results?
docs.snippet: Fed up parents, civil rights activists, newly awakened educators and lawmakers are crusading for “the science of reading.” Can they get results?
docs.lead_paragraph: In suburban Houston, parents rose up against a top-rated school district, demanding an entirely new reading curriculum.

headline.main: ‘Kids Can’t Read’: The Revolt That Is Taking On the Education Establishment
headline.print_headline: ‘Kids Can’t Read,’ and the Education Establishment Faces a Revolt

docs.abstract: A new report from PEN America, the free speech organization, details a new rise of censorship efforts across the United States.
docs.snippet: A new report from PEN America, the free speech organization, details a new rise of censorship efforts across the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: Book bans are rising at a rapid pace in school districts around the United States, driven by new laws and regulations that limit what kinds of books children can access, according to a new report from PEN America, a free speech organization.

headline.main: Book Bans Rising Rapidly in the U.S., Free Speech Groups Find

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to respond when a peer engages in fraud.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to respond when a peer engages in fraud.
docs.lead_paragraph: My friend told me that she and her husband, who combined earn around $500,000, asked their son’s stepmother to declare him on her taxes for the last two years so that he could get more financial aid for college. Their son doesn’t even live with the stepmother, and she provides no support.

headline.main: My Rich Friend Lied to Get Financial Aid. Should I Confront Her?

docs.abstract: The nation’s school system still sees the country’s pupils starkly divided by their religious backgrounds, years after the Good Friday Agreement brought an end to sectarian strife.
docs.snippet: The nation’s school system still sees the country’s pupils starkly divided by their religious backgrounds, years after the Good Friday Agreement brought an end to sectarian strife.
docs.lead_paragraph: On weekday mornings, Mark Lynn, 10, walks past the 40-foot-tall metal fence looming over his backyard at the edge of his predominantly Catholic neighborhood in Belfast, and heads to his Catholic school, its crest displayed prominently on his blue sweater.

headline.main: Decades on From Peace, Northern Ireland Schools Are Still Deeply Divided
headline.print_headline: Peace Endures in Belfast, but the School Day Is Still Deeply Divided

byline.original: By Megan Specia and Andrew Testa

docs.abstract: Three schools challenged the settlement, which would forgive $6 billion, saying the Biden administration had colluded with plaintiffs and exceeded its authority.
docs.snippet: Three schools challenged the settlement, which would forgive $6 billion, saying the Biden administration had colluded with plaintiffs and exceeded its authority.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to block a class-action settlement that forgave $6 billion in federal loans for students at for-profit schools or vocational programs.

headline.main: Supreme Court Won’t Block Student Loan Class-Action Settlement

docs.abstract: Liam Squires, a fifth grader in Virginia, found a mistake in a book’s diagram of the rock cycle. The publisher said it was “proud” of his discovery.
docs.snippet: Liam Squires, a fifth grader in Virginia, found a mistake in a book’s diagram of the rock cycle. The publisher said it was “proud” of his discovery.
docs.lead_paragraph: Liam Squires, like many students, usually answers the question “How was school today?” with an evasive answer along the lines of “I don’t know.”

headline.main: Virginia Fifth Grader Is Celebrated for Spotting Textbook’s Error
headline.print_headline: It’s Rock Science: Fifth Grader Spots Error in Textbook

docs.abstract: After more than a dozen elite schools decided not to participate, the publication tweaked its methodology. And the ratings looked … not that different.
docs.snippet: After more than a dozen elite schools decided not to participate, the publication tweaked its methodology. And the ratings looked … not that different.
docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. News & World Report issued new rankings on Tuesday for the nation’s Top 14 law schools and Top 15 medical schools, just months after many of the schools dropped out of the rankings, saying they were unreliable and unfair.

headline.main: U.S. News Releases New Rankings for Top Law and Medical Schools, Despite a Boycott

docs.abstract: If approved, the online Catholic school would be funded by taxpayer dollars, teeing up a high-profile constitutional battle.
docs.snippet: If approved, the online Catholic school would be funded by taxpayer dollars, teeing up a high-profile constitutional battle.
docs.lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma state education board is weighing whether to approve the nation’s first religious charter school this spring, potentially setting up a high-profile constitutional battle over whether taxpayer money can be used to directly fund religious schools.

headline.main: Nation’s First Religious Charter School Could Be Coming to Oklahoma
headline.print_headline: Oklahoma Considers Nation’s First Religious Charter School

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICANS UNITED FOR SEPARATION OF CHURCH AND STATE

byline.original: By Sarah Mervosh and Ruth Graham

docs.abstract: Officials were working on a plan to protect transgender athletes since the day the president was sworn in. In recent months, they raced to issue protections as states moved to revoke them.
docs.snippet: Officials were working on a plan to protect transgender athletes since the day the president was sworn in. In recent months, they raced to issue protections as states moved to revoke them.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Biden signed an executive order in his first hours in office to strengthen prohibitions against gender and sexual discrimination, a small team of officials in the Department of Education began assessing an unanswered but important question: How could the administration protect transgender athletes?

headline.main: Biden Plan for Transgender Title IX Rules Began on Inauguration Day
headline.print_headline: Officials Began Work on Protections on Day 1

docs.abstract: The Biden administration proposed a rule change that would allow schools to block some transgender athletes from competing on sports teams that match their gender identities.
docs.snippet: The Biden administration proposed a rule change that would allow schools to block some transgender athletes from competing on sports teams that match their gender identities.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on April 6 released long-awaited draft rules regarding the participation of transgender athletes in school sports, taking its first official stand on a matter that has become a contentious public debate. The rule would have broad implications for the ability of athletes from elementary school T-ball to the N.C.A.A. level to play.

headline.main: Title IX and the New Rule on Transgender Athletes Explained
headline.print_headline: Explaining the New Rule on Transgender Athletes
